ranked_diseases.explanation: Freckling, particularly in the axillary and inguinal regions, is one of the major diagnostic criteria for NF1. This is the most common disorder presenting with freckling as a primary feature.
Also known as NF1-like syndrome, presents with café-au-lait macules and freckling similar to NF1 but without neurofibromas. Caused by SPRED1 mutations.
Can present with café-au-lait macules and pigmentary changes, though freckling is less typical. The pigmentary changes usually have irregular borders.
Previously known as LEOPARD syndrome, presents with multiple lentigines that could be interpreted as freckling, though typically develops later and has additional features.
Can present with spotty skin pigmentation including lentigines and blue nevi, though isolated freckling would be unusual without other features.
Presents with mucocutaneous pigmentation, particularly perioral, but can have freckling-like lesions. Usually has gastrointestinal polyps as well.
